Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RMY-PPW1-JC8Y-819F-00000-00Using pencil and paper to vote doesn't seem so silly now2018-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 12Using pencil and paper to vote doesn't seem so silly nowKathy Sheridan

Opinion writers stand accused of undue negativity, so make way for a few heart-lifting positives. Well-thumbed physical election registers. Paper ballots. Stubby pencils. Interminable counts surveyed by gimlet-eyed tallymen and women. That's our fabulously antiquated voting system and it stands up well.

Last week, by contrast, Americans learned that the electronic voting systems of 21 states were targeted by Russian hackers in 2016 and some had been "actually successfully penetrated", in the words of the US head of cybersecurity. The targeting may have been exploratory probes for system vulnerabilities to be exploited later, say experts, pointing to the crumbling US digital voting apparatus.

In other words, the 2016 hackers could look like plankton compared with the shark attacks expected around the forthcoming midterm elections, with their potential to rebalance power in America.

Or not. Have the magpie media once again fallen headlong for the shiny clickbait - a hacking conspiracy thriller - and, as some suggest, taken their eye off the more significant story of the 2016 election campaign? That is, the triumph of propaganda by social media advertisements, trolls and bots.

We know now that online giants such as Facebook and Twitter enabled Russian operatives to inflame the polarisation of American society. Twitter has provided a list to a US Senate committee with the user names of nearly 37,000 Russian-linked bots that tweeted a total of 1.4 million times. If that sounds tame, consider this : those 1.4 million tweets were viewed 288 million times.

Facebook has admitted that 11.4 million Americans definitely saw Russian troll-farm advertisements like this: "Hillary is Satan, and her crimes and lies have proved just how evil she is. And even though Donald Trump is not a saint by any means, at least he is an honest man and he cares deeply for this country." Sweet. Between clicking and sharing, it's likely that half the US population saw this post.

In the final weeks, the top five fake news items were all negatives for the Clinton campaign. "In other words, the Facebook algorithm picked a side - it's not neutral," writes lecturer and author Rachel Botsman in the Observer. Facebook is "a media company with enormous influence in shaping someone's worldview about whom to trust. And it is profit-driven."

Russian-linked accounts

Closer to home, she cites a study on the period leading up to the Brexit referendum, in which one-third of Twitter traffic appears to have come from scripted bots mainly spreading pro-Leave content. Another study of the 48 hours around the vote shows that Russian-linked accounts posted more than 45,000 pro-Brexit tweets - and for every original bot tweet, seven retweets were made by humans. Think about that in the context of the margin between Leave and Remain. And think about motivation and funding sources.

We can argue the toss on whether the focus should be on hacked voting machinery or Big Tech's global distortion of trust. Either way, Putin's work is done. A new NBC News/SurveyMonkey poll suggests that four out of five Americans are somewhat or very concerned that the country's voting system might be vulnerable to computer hackers.

The 2018 Edelman Trust Barometer reports that 63 per cent of its 33,000 respondents across 28 countries say they no longer know how to tell good journalism from rumour or falsehoods. Who are that confident 37 per cent? The canny, well-informed? Think of the fake tweets innocently repeated by credible news and current affairs presenters.

Mission accomplished then for Trump and brethren whose best hope for gaining or retaining power is to sow political chaos by undermining confidence in the voting system, the media, regulators and democracy itself.

There are glimmers of hope. Online platforms that once looked invincible have had to explain themselves before powerful government committees and face a gathering threat to their vital advertising revenue. Unilever - the world's second-biggest marketing spender, at about EUR 8 billion a year, one-third of it spent online - has just threatened to pull its online advertising from giant platforms that are "little better than a swamp in terms of transparency".

Trust

Another glimmer appears in the Edelman study, which reports a striking 13-point rise in support for traditional media, while only one-quarter now trust the likes of Twitter, Facebook and Instagram for news and information.

Which brings us back to the stubby pencils and lessons learned. In the early 2000s, the then taoiseach Bertie Ahern said we were a "laughing stock" with our use of the "peann luaidhe", and so the Fianna Fáil lads fluttered EUR 51 million on electronic voting machines with no paper trail or independent verification. Trust the lads, was the message. Without the combined firepower of media, experts like Margaret McGaley and thinking politicians, we too might be living in terror of hack attacks on our voting system.

That EUR 51 million pile of scrap metal remains a scandal, but a cheap lesson in the end for democracy.

urn:contentItem:5XSX-72F1-F03R-N3YV-00000-00Using Trump As A Prop, The Myth Of 'Anonymized' Cell Data Is Finally Exposed2019-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisUsing Trump As A Prop, The Myth Of 'Anonymized' Cell Data Is Finally ExposedKarl Bode

Dec 20, 2019( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) As companies and governments increasingly hoover up our personal data, a common refrain to keep people from worrying is the claim that nothing can go wrong because the data itself is "anonymized"--or stripped of personal detail. But time[1] and time[2] again, studies have shown[3] how this really is cold comfort; given it takes only a little effort to pretty quickly identify a person based on access to other data sets[4]. Yet most companies, policy folk, and government officials still act as if "anonymizing" your data means something. It's simply not true. While that point hasn't yet resonated with the public and press fully, it should now.

The second in an amazing 7 series saga by the New York Times[5] was released this week, taking a closer look at a data trove of 50 billion location pings from the phones of more than 12 million Americans given to the Times by an anonymous insider at one of countless location data brokers. The first[6] in the Times' series took a look at how easy it was to identify "anonymized" normal citizens and track their everyday lives. This second piece[7] ups the ante by... easily tracking the President of the United States via the location data of one of his secret service agents:"The meticulous movements — down to a few feet — of the president's entourage were recorded by a smartphone we believe belonged to a Secret Service agent, whose home was also clearly identifiable in the data. Connecting the home to public deeds revealed the person's name, along with the name of the person's spouse, exposing even more details about both families. We could also see other stops this person made, apparently more connected with his private life than his public duties. The Secret Service declined to comment on our findings or describe its policies regarding location data."I'm not sure I've ever seen a story that more perfectly encapsulates both the stupidity of the "anonymized data is a panacea" claim, as well as the government's feckless refusal to seriously address one of the biggest scandals in privacy history. Granted it wasn't just the daily movement habits of the President's security detail that the data revealed, but that of Congressional staffers and lawmakers, many of whom have similarly been utterly apathetic to the problem:"We were able to track smartphones in nearly every major government building and facility in Washington. We could follow them back to homes and, ultimately, their owners' true identities. Even a prominent senator's national security adviser — someone for whom privacy and security are core to their every working day — was identified and tracked in the data."DC lawmakers could use this as a learning opportunity to finally understand why location data--whether it comes from an app or your cellular provider--shouldn't be treated cavalierly and sold to every nitwit with a nickel. Granted, it's just as likely the end lesson government learns is a focus on better location data security for government officials, and nobody else. As we've noted for a while, "feckless" is the best term to describe the government's response to a steady[8] parade of scandals[9] showing this data is routinely abused from everybody from rogue law enforcement officers[10] to crazed stalkers[11]. The Congressional response to the Times' latest report was bipartisan in nature, even though a desire to actually do something about it hasn't been. Recall Congress voted along strict party lines to kill FCC broadband privacy rules in 2017[12] that could have at least partially addressed the problem. The GOP also supported the erosion of FCC authority in the net neutrality repeal[13], which also opened the door to greater abuse. Still, when the check comes due for those policy moves, notice how the outrage is suddenly bipartisan:"This is terrifying,' said Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, who has called for the federal government take a tougher stance with tech companies. 'It is terrifying not just because of the major national security implications, what Beijing could get ahold of. But it also raises personal privacy concerns for individuals and families. These companies are tracking our kids." 'Tech companies are profiting by spying on Americans — trampling on the right to privacy and risking our national security,' Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat running for president, told us. 'They are throwing around their power to undermine our democracy with zero consequences. This report is another alarming case for why we need to break up big tech, adopt serious privacy regulations and hold top executives of these companies personally responsible.'The FCC's supposed investigation into carrier location data sales appears to be stuck in neutral, with growing concerns[14] the agency is running out the clock[15] to avoid having to hold industry accountable. There's no real effort to craft rules that prohibit the widespread collection and sale of such data, and most policy conversations remain fixated exclusively on big tech, despite the problem also being rampant in big telecom. Meanwhile, our quest for an actual US privacy law in the internet are remains stuck in neutral, in large part because industry doesn't want to lose billions to consumers opting out of having their every waking moment monetized. Still, the Times report (which many gearing up for the holidays won't read) may help finally dislodge some of this apathy and drive some actual, fact-based awareness of the real scope of the problem, maybe someday resulting in actual, serious proposals to fix it.Permalink[16] | Comments[17] | Email This Story[18] [ 1]: urn:contentItem:5NWP-F7M1-JC0X-K2HM-00000-00US:International markets roundup2017-06-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL NEWSUS:International markets roundupSYDNEY June 28

  NEW YORK: The tech-heavy Nasdaq has led a broad Wall Street decline with stocks falling more sharply after a healthcare bill was delayed in the US Senate, raising fresh questions about President Trump's domestic agenda.


   The benchmark S&P 500 posted its biggest one-day drop in about six weeks and closed at its lowest point since May 31.
   Major indexes extended losses after US Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell decided to put off a planned vote on a bill to dismantle the Affordable Care Act until after the Senate's July 4 recess.
   The healthcare legislation, which has encountered resistance from several Republicans, is the first plank of Trump's domestic policy agenda, with investors eager for him to move onto his other plans including tax cuts, infrastructure spending and deregulation.
   The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.46 per cent to 21,310.66, the S&P 500 lost 0.81 per cent to 2419.38 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.61 per cent to 6146.62.
   Big tech names weighed most heavily on the SP 500. Google parent Alphabet fell 2.5 per cent after EU antitrust regulators hit the tech giant with a record $2.7-billion ($A3.6b) fine.
   The Nasdaq had its worst day since a tech-led slide on June 9 raised questions about the sector.
   LONDON: Hawkish comments from European Central Bank president Mario Draghi hit interest rate-sensitive utilities shares on Tuesday, dragging down European indexes, while a warning from auto parts supplier Schaeffler hit the whole sector.
   Draghi on Tuesday opened the door to tweaks in the bank's aggressive stimulus policy, fuelling market expectations the bank will announce a reduction of stimulus as soon as September.
   Utilities, whose constant dividends flows become less attractive when monetary policy tightens, fell 2.4 per cent, suffering their biggest one day loss since November.
   Their losses helped drag the pan-European STOXX 600 index down 0.8 per cent.
   However shares in banks, which have long suffered from the ECB's ultra loose policy, were boosted by Draghi's remarks with the eurozone sectoral index ending up 1.4 per cent.
   Germany's DAX lost 0.8 per cent to12,671.02
   Britain's FTSE inched lower, weighed down by losses among pharma stocks, while updates from Carpetright and Debenhams gave conflicting pictures of the health of British consumers as inflationary pressures start to bite.
   The FTSE 100 ended down 0.2 per cent at 7,434.36, erasing almost all the previous session's gains, with the pharma sector taking most points off the blue chip index.
   TOKYO: Japanese stocks edged towards two-year highs on Tuesday as exporters benefited from US dollar strength, with investors expecting comments from Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen to support the central bank's projection for one more interest rate rise this year.
   Yellen is scheduled to take part in a discussion on global economic issues at London's Royal Academy and a number of other top Fed officials are also due to speak later in the global day.
   Japan's benchmark Nikkei rose 0.4 per cent to 20,225.09 in subdued trading.
   Hong Kong stocks dipped, as any optimism from solid China industrial profit data was offset by the sour mood from a tumble in the growth enterprise market (GEM) for start-ups due to worries over potential policy changes.
   The Hang Seng index fell 0.1 per cent, to 25,839.99, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.3 per cent, to 10,498.07 points.
   Investors largely looked past news that profits at China's industrial companies surged 16.7 per cent in May from a year earlier.
   China stocks recouped earlier losses to end higher, but investors turned cautious amid a strong rally in blue-chips after MSCI decided last week to add 222 China-listed stocks to its Emerging Markets Index.
   The blue-chip CSI300 index rose 0.2 per cent, to 3,674.72 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index also added 0.2 per cent to 3,191.20 points.
   WELLINGTON:The SP/NZX 50 Index climbed 0.4 per cent to 7626.35.

urn:contentItem:5NX4-CMK1-JC0X-K43V-00000-00US:International markets roundup2017-06-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL NEWSUS:International markets roundupSYDNEY June 30

  NEW YORK: Wall Street has fallen sharply, with the S&P 500 and the Dow industrials suffering their worst daily percentage drops in about six weeks, as a recent decline in technology shares deepened and outweighed strength in bank shares.


   The technology sector, which has led the S&P 500's 8-per cent gain for the year, dropped 1.8 per cent, and were the worst-performing major group. Declines in big tech stocks, including Apple and Microsoft, weighed the most on the benchmark S&P.
   Financials and energy were the only sectors in positive territory as investors may have been rotating into groups that have lagged this year.
   The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.78 per cent to 21,287.03, the S&P 500 lost 0.86 per cent to 2419.7 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped or 1.44 per cent to 6144.35.
   The CBOE Volatility index, the widely followed barometer of expected near-term stock market volatility, rose to a six-week high of 15.16, before paring some of the move.
   LONDON: European shares logged their biggest one-day loss in nine months on Thursday as interest rate-sensitive sectors were hit by a rising hawkish chorus from central banks globally.
   The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended 1.3 per cent lower, extending falls just before the US market open, while European blue chips fell 1.8 per cent.
   Germany's DAX lost 1.8 per cent to close at 12,416.19.
   Signals that central bankers are becoming more hawkish sent bond yields rising, which weighed on defensive, dividend-paying sectors including Europe's personal and household goods sector , health care and food and beverages, which were all down 2 per cent or more.
   On Tuesday European Central Bank President Mario Draghi indicated that the central bank could begin to tighten monetary policy, though sources said on Wednesday that Draghi had been overinterpreted by markets.
   Likewise, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney on Wednesday said a rise in British interest rates is likely to be needed as the economy comes closer to running at full capacity.
   Robust bank and mining stocks helped Britain's FTSE 100 index outpace European peers on Thursday.
   Britain's main share index ended 0.5 per cent lower, at 7,350.32, having spent much of the session in positive territory.
   British banks, a sector which would benefit from higher rates, jumped 2.7 percent to a four-month high after the US regulator approved higher dividends and buybacks, sending a ripple effect across financial stocks worldwide.
   TOKYO: Asian stocks rose on Thursday after the Federal Reserve approved plans from the 34 largest US banks to use extra capital for stock buy backs and dividends.
   Japan's Nikkei adding 0.45 per cent to 20,220.30 and MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan rose 0.8 per cent to its highest since May 2015.
   Hong Kong's Hang Seng lifted 1.10 per cent to 25,965.42.
   China stocks rose, driven by strong gains in raw material shares as a weaker US dollar lifted commodities prices.
   Sentiment was also boosted by easing fears of a quarter-end liquidity crunch in the banking system, as well as a rise in the yuan, which assuaged concerns about capital outflows.
   The blue-chip CSI300 index rose 0.6 per cent, to 3,668.83 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.5 per cent to 3,188.06 points.
   WELLINGTON:The SP/NZX 50 Index gained 0.8 per cent to 7685.45.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJ7-GM01-DYG3-32D8-00000-00US Internet giants called to Congress2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisUS Internet giants called to CongressNick Wood, for Total Telecom

House committee investigating the huge market power wielded by likes of Amazon, Google, Facebook, Apple

Executives from US Web giants will appear at the US Capitol next week, as the government tries to ascertain just how powerful the likes of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google have become.Reuters reports that the antitrust subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee will hear testimony next Tuesday from Adam Cohen, director of economic policy at Google; Nate Sutton, associate general counsel for regulation at Amazon; Matt Perault, head of global policy development at Facebook; and Kyle Andeer, vice president of corporate law at Apple.The hearing forms part of a bipartisan investigation launched in June into competition in digital markets. The Committee noted at the time that "a small number of dominant, unregulated platforms have extraordinary power over commerce, communication, and information online."The investigation aims to document any problems with competition in digital markets; establish whether the aforementioned Internet giants are engaging in anti-competitive behaviour; and assess whether existing legislation is sufficient to address any issues.Given Google's record of infringing EU antitrust laws due certain practices relating to online search, its comparison shopping service, and its Android operating system, there could be at least one Internet player feeling slightly hot under the collar.One prominent politician will certainly pay closer attention than most to the investigation.Democratic presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren has repeatedly called for Amazon, Google and Facebook to be broken in order to address antitrust concerns."Today's big tech companies have too much power ?

too much power over our economy, our society, and our democracy. They've bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else. And in the process, they have hurt small businesses and stifled innovation," the Senator from Massachusetts wrote earlier this year.

urn:contentItem:602B-1M41-JBJN-M435-00000-00US investigates whether Spanish Google rate that today debates Congress discriminates against its trade2020-06-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisUS investigates whether SpanishGoogle rate that today debates Congress discriminates against its trade


The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative has opened an investigation into digital taxes unilaterally envisaged by nine countries, including Spain, and throughout the European Union. The US administration will thus review the so-called Google rate that the Government of Pedro Sánchez intends to apply to internet giants, companies such as the American companies Facebook, Microsoft or Netflix.


The focus of this research is on Austria, Brazil, the Czech Republic, India, Indonesia, Italy, Turkey,the United Kingdom, the whole of the European Union and Spain, which in one way or another seek formulas to tax the commercial activity that these large online corporations carry out in these territories. In the Spanish case, the Tax on Certain Digital Services (IDSD) would establish a levy of 3% of revenue (non-profits), provided that the companies concerned exceed 750 million euros of global turnover and 3 million euros in this country.
The communication of the beginning of this procedure occurred only a few hours before the plenary session of Congress discusses the bill for the implementation of this tax. The US warns that, in compliance with sections 301 of its regulations, it will examine whether such measures are"inadmissible or discriminatory and charge or restrict US trade".
The digital economy is stirring
This initiative by donald Trump's presiding country has also coincided with a joint communiqué of the digital economic environment against the launch of a Spanish tax unilaterally, without waiting for the joint agreement currently being pursued under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).
The organizations and employers of the AMETIC sector, IAB Spain, the Spanish Association of Startups and the Spanish Association of the Digital Economy (Adigital) have expressed their rejection of this project and"ask the Government of Spain to reconsider its position until an agreement is reached at the international level".
These entities argue that such a tax would eventually pass on to more modest but Big Tech-dependent digital companies such as Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple, not to mention a foreseeable impact on consumers. Moreover, in the view of these organizations, the Spanish economy would be with this tax"less productive, less innovative,less entrepreneurial and, consequently, less competitive globally".
For now, the U.S. investigation is in a first phase, dedicated to gathering comments and suggestions from the parties involved, but this same procedure is the one that the Trump Administration used to paralyze France's digital rate. American Trade decided to impose 100% tariffs on French imports as iconic as cheese or wine. Negotiations between French President Emmanuel Macron and his counterpart Donald Trump helped stop those tariffs along with the google fee charge. at least until the end of the year, pending the OECD's calculations.
In this regard, Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer stated that "the United States would take action against those digital tax regimes that discriminate or otherwise impose undue burdens on American companies."

urn:contentItem:53B3-KG81-JC11-909W-00000-00U.S. Is Again Threatened with a Credit Rating Downgrade; Pentagon Suffers Cyber Attack; Casey Anthony to be Released on Sunday; Second Computer Failure on Space Shuttle Atlantis; Suicide Bomber Kills Five in Attack; Gay History Lessons Coming to California Classrooms; Budget Negotiations; Credit Rating Effect; Laura Ingraham Repeat Package; Obama News Conference; John Stossel Interview; Interview With Lou Dobbs, Dr. Keith Ablow2011-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisIMUS IN THE MORNING6:00 AM ESTMichael Graham, Alex Rossi, Lou Dobbs, Keith AblowNEWSInternational071501cb.220U.S. Is Again Threatened with a Credit Rating Downgrade; Pentagon Suffers Cyber Attack; Casey Anthony to be Released on Sunday; Second Computer Failure on Space Shuttle Atlantis; Suicide Bomber Kills Five in Attack; Gay History Lessons Coming to California Classrooms; Budget Negotiations; Credit Rating Effect; Laura Ingraham Repeat Package; Obama News Conference; John Stossel Interview; Interview With Lou Dobbs, Dr. Keith AblowDagen McDowell, Connell McShane, Diane Macedo, Peter Barnes, Adam Shapiro, Mike Emanuel, John Stossel, Katie Sargent, Bret Baier, Stuart Varney, Doug Luzader, Ray Hennessey

DON IMUS, HOST OF IMUS IN THE MORNING: This is the IMUS IN THE MORNING program on the Fox Business Networkand now here's Diane Macedo.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, for the second time in two days, U.S. government's credit rating is being threatened with a downgrade. S&P now saying, there's a 50 percent chance they'll drop the U.S. from his AAA status as the impact over the death ceiling continues.

Meanwhile, it appears some progress is actually being made in the ongoing talks between the White House and congressional leaders. President Obama will talk about it. News conference today from president, 11:00 a.m. Eastern Time, which of course will carry live here on Fox Business.

And, there's word out of the pentagon that it suffered one of the largest cyber attacks ever; 24,000 files, some of them are extremely sensitive were stolen. U.S. officials believe it was a work of foreign government.

And, Casey Anthony scheduled to be released from prison on Sunday after being acquitted of murdering her daughter, but there are some real concerns over her safety, so we'll talk about that. So, all of those stories coming up. Good morning, everybody. Along with Dagen McDowell, I am Connell McShane. Welcome to IMUS IN THE MORNING on this Friday morning and --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Are you feeling all right?

MCSHANE: I'm all right.

MCDOWELL: Your voice --

MCSHANE: A little bit weird, yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes, it sounds weird.

MCSHANE: Thank you for bringing it up --

MCDOWELL: But in a good way.

MCSHANE: Right on top of the show.

(LAUGHING)

MCDOWELL: I was just saying -- I'm just keeping it real. I worry about you.

MCSHANE: Really?

MCDOWELL: Deeply. All the time.

MCSHANE: Is that what you do in the evenings and stuff.

MCDOWELL: Yes. That's all I do pretty much.

MCSHANE: How's --

MCDOWELL: You know what? We watch the show and just admire you. That's what I do.

(LAUGHING)

MCSHANE: You have a lot of problems.

MCDOWELL: Well, do the markets have problems? That's what we cover here at the Fox Business Network. You can take a look at how the stock market futures are. They are all in the green this morning. The Dow Futures up 25 and I think it is safe to say if you want to take a look at oil as well. There you go -- Oil is down to $0.15 a barrel.

They get safe to say that there has been perforate little reaction to these warnings from the credit rating agencies, Moody's and then S&P and then the fighting. The increasingly -- emotional fighting down in DC. You have seen no reaction in the bond markets and the treasury markets.

MCSHANE: No, nothing.

MCDOWELL: The tenure treasury is still below 3 percent.

MCSHANE: Yes, it is safe to say that. No doubt about it. Now, Pres. Obama giving congressional leaderships a break from the debt talks today, but he'll be giving an update on the negotiations later this morning and from Fox News Doug Luzader is in DC for us. What's the latest, Doug?

DOUGLAS LUZADER, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. Well, big press conference today from the president. Second one, I think this week on this. So, kind of unusual, but he's trying to get his side out there, neither side in the overall debate has budged. And, with his August 2nd deadline rapidly approaching, it is getting personal.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LUZADER (voice-over): They met yet again at the White House and again came up short, just for good measure, the administration sent Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner to congress with a stark warning.

TIMOTHY GEITHNER, TREASURY SECRETARY: We have no way to give congress more time to solve this problem.

LUZADER: The problem is clear. We're just about to run out of borrowed money, but the solution isn't. And, it may not help but the negotiations could be spinning out of control and just look at how crowded this room is.

PRES. BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: There's just too many people in there poring cold water and virtually every idea -- another table.

LUZADER: Raise taxes or make deeper budget cuts. That is the dividing line. Senate Minority leader Mitch McConnell is still trying to sell his back-up plan, which allows the president to barrow more but take a political hit in the process. Other republicans like Congressman Eric Cantor will not give in to new taxes though and he carries a great deal of sway in these talks.

PRES. OBAMA: I am willing to work with everybody including Eric Cantor to solve problems, and my relationship with all the leaders has been cordial. It has been professional, but I think at a certain point, the American people have run out of patience.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LUZADER: And, hey congress is set to run out patience too. There was an idea floated yesterday. They have everyone travel to Camp David for more talks. Both democrats and republicans immediately shut it down, and it went no where -- Connell.

MCSHANE: All right, now working on the weekend, I guess. Doug, thank you. Doug Luzader there from Fox News live in Washington.

MCDOWELL: Your worst nightmare being stuck up at Camp David with people who you were not getting along with. It's like a bad family reunion.

MCSHANE: It looks like this McConnell plan for all it's worth is gaining a lot of attraction.

MCDOWELL: He comes together with Harry Reid and it could be the end of the president. He said he'd be willing to do it. You know, willing to be the point man.

MCSHANE: Well, they have nothing else at this point and that's the only thing that --

MCDOWELL: Sadly enough. Sadly enough.

MCSHANE: Had anything -- any kind of support, so we'll see.

MCDOWELL: Diane, give us some good news. Diane Macedo is all over your business headlines today.

DIANE MACEDO, FBN CORRESPONDENT: I don't if I can help you out with good news right now, but I can give you news.

MCDOWELL: Do that.

(LAUGHING)

MACEDO: Rebecca Brooks has resigned as chief executive of news international. Now, that's the unit of news corporation that has been at the center of an investigation over phone hacking. Tom Mockridge, head of Sky Italia, was named as a replacement.

Brooks said in a note to the staff that she was quitting to concentrate in the investigations in the hacking and, quote, "correcting the distortions about her record." News corp. is apparent to the Fox Business Network. Now, lets check on the Asian markets and for that we'll go to Fox Business Contributor Katy Sargent, who joins us by phone. Good morning, Katy.

KATY SARGENT, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, good morning, Diane. We have some mixed result in Asia today going into the weekend, starting in Japan, the Nikei adding 0.4 percent. Shares are at 0.7 percent helped by gains among tech giants like LG electronics and SK telecom.

The property stocks really put pressure on China's market after Beijing after Beijing announced some further new home purchase limits. The Hang Seng finished down 0.4 percent. The Shanghai composite started out lower, but it recovered its early losses. It finished with the gain of about 0.4 percent.

Some of the big exporters doing well in Tokyo today with Cannon and Sony, both up about 1 percent. But, that retailing which owns the clothing chain dropped 0.7 percent after posting yet another drop in quarterly profit. Sales has been sagging down in the wake of the earthquake and tsunami.

The trading very cautious in the region. Investors taking in factors like the standards, of course, warning on U.S. debt and stress test for European banks. MACEDO: Good morning, everyone.

Let's kick things off with a look at the markets. Taking a look at futures right now. They're in green territory. Dow futures are up 48 points. The S&P's up 5. And the Nasdaq's up almost 11. Markets aren't affected that much by the warning from S&P. I mean, as you can see, futures are up. And coming up in just a few minutes, we'll get the latest look at the consumer index price.

Now, Citigroup, meanwhile, is reporting better than expected earnings. Net income is $3.3 billion. That works out to $1.09 per share. The estimate was 96 cents a share. And revenue came in at $20.62 billion, also beating the estimates. The company says credit losses declined 35 percent from the same time a year ago. And shares, as you can imagine, are rising in the pre- market.

Connell, back to you.

MCSHANE: All right, Diane.

Now, dueling news conferences coming up. We're going to have the GOP leadership at the top of the next hour, 9:00 a.m. Eastern Time. And then President Obama at 11:00. So, Mike Emanuel -- let's go back to the White House, where Mike Emanuel, the White House correspondent for Fox News, is there for us this morning.

What do we expect to hear -- it's almost like deja vu all over again here, Mike -- from the president this time around?

MIKE EMANUEL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Connell, it's interesting because after five consecutive days of meetings here at the White House, behind closed doors with congressional leaders, it became pretty apparent that a grand bargain that the president was hoping for was not going to happen. So he sent them back to Capitol Hill and said, I'm giving you 24 to 36 hours to see what you guys can come up with. We may do some meetings over the course of the weekend.

But, for now, essentially what they're doing is dueling press conferences. House Republicans within the hour taking their case directly to the American people. Then the president of the United States at 11:00 Eastern Time will make his case about essentially what he wants to do. And he's tried to frame himself as the adult in the room during these negotiations. So you can expect more of that, Connell.

MCDOWELL: Mike, it's Dagen McDowell.

So do you think that the rhetoric will get increasingly, for lack of a better word, nasty? Because you have president -- the president book-ending the week with press conferences, which, correct me if I'm wrong, we haven't seen during his presidency. And I just wonder, because you have leaks coming out about what is said behind the scenes, and this is a way for certainly the Republicans to get out in front of it.

EMANUEL: You know, Dagen, it's been quite a study. You're correct, the president can go months without doing a full-blown news conference. This will be his third in two weeks. So clearly feeling like taking his case directly to the American people puts pressure on lawmakers to get something done.

But it hasn't worked so far. And so will today be different? We know that time is running out. The August 2nd deadline is coming in a hurry. But the politics of this are difficult because there are some House Republicans who are not going to vote for raising the debt ceiling no matter what. There are some Democrats who are not going to want to touch entitlement reform at all. And there are a lot of Republicans who are not going to want to raise taxes. And so everybody's in their respective corners, if you will. Willing to compromise a bit, but not enough to get the votes necessary to pass a bipartisan, major deal through Congress at this point.

So they're looking for smaller compromises. The Mitch McConnell plus plan is something that may be taking shape on Capitol Hill. So it's something we're watching to see what happens.

MCSHANE: All right, Mike, good to see you, as always. Good stuff. Mike Emanuel from the White House from Fox News.

EMANUEL: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: And we are joined now on the phone by John Stossel of the Fox Business Network.

John, thanks so much for calling in this morning. I want to get your reaction to what you see going on down in Washington. And it's really erupted into what looks like to be a nasty little fight or a nasty big fight between the Republicans and the Democrats.

JOHN STOSSEL, FOX NEWS (via telephone): Well, it's a big issue. So we ought to have a nasty, big fight. I just think, isn't $2.5 trillion enough? It's about a trillion more than they spent just a couple of years ago. They ought to be able to find enough money in there to pay the debt we owe.

MCSHANE: So you figure that then both sides should give and we should -- or maybe already had a deal done or that this grand bargain, the $4 trillion number that they were talking about, is just a little bit too -- a little bit too much?

STOSSEL: Well, no, I disagree with both those points. I don't know that both should give in. I think if one side is saying we need higher taxes so we can keep spending more --

MCSHANE: Right.

STOSSEL: Then that's a bad argument. And $4 trillion doesn't sound like all that much to me when it's over 10 years when we're spending, what, $46 trillion projected in those 10 years? Companies cut 10 percent every five years. I remember when Cap Cities took over ABC. They just cut 10 percent and we (ph) -- oh, it's terrible. We can't deal with that. We made the adjustment. Happened again when somebody else bought Cap Cities. Disney bought Cap Cities. And they had a -- GE used to call that the creative destruction that keeps your company going.

MCSHANE: Yes.

STOSSEL: That was when GE was a growth company rather than just sucking from the government.

MCDOWELL: Well said, John Stossel.

John, and that really leads us to what you did on your show last night, because we're talking about -- because you're equating what's going on in Washington with what happens in business very often. And you looked at Herman Cain last night and asked the question of, is it now time for this country to elect a businessman. But did you find that Americans -- the American people knew who Herman was?

STOSSEL: No. I walked around Times Square with a big picture of him and maybe one in 15 knew who he was. Though some people said, oh, yes, he's that guy who owns the pizza shop, right?

I argued last night that -- I don't know that Herman Cain is the one who would be a good president, but he's mocked by some in the political class for not having had political experience, but why does that qualify you to be president, because you're experienced at smiling at people when you don't mean it and asking people for money and sucking up to people that would make you a good president? At least a businessman has -- a business person, sorry, has had experience in managing things and knows that you can't spend more money than you have or you'd go out of business.

MCSHANE: What about that challenge, though, of being taken or being considered to be a quote/unquote serious candidate? Is that something somebody like Herman Cain can overcome? And, if so, how does he go about doing it?

STOSSEL: Beats me. Not my area, politics. But, you know, what -- I'm just trying to think. Was Arnold Schwarzenegger not considered a serious candidate? And he got overwhelmingly elected despite having come straight from the movie world. Ronald Reagan wasn't considered a serious candidate by the in crowd.

MCSHANE: True.

MCDOWELL: John, that is a very good point. We're going to need to wrap it up here with you. We're going to have some breaking news coming out.

John, it was terrific to see you and it's always great to see you on the air, whether it's on the phone or in person. John Stossel of the Fox Business Network. Take care.

And we wanted to just keep a lookout on this news that's going to be coming across. Consumer prices. We're going to get the reading from the past month on that. And also we're going to be looking at the Empire State Manufacturing index. Again, manufacturing has been erratic and fairly weak in recently weeks and recent months.

MCSHANE: It was a market mover last time around. So the CPI Index is out, and it's down .2 of one percent.

MCDOWELL: Two-tenths.

MCSHANE: A little bit more than expected.

MCDOWELL: A little bit more than expected.

If you look at core inflation, core inflation increased .3 of a percent. This is excluding food and energy prices, which -- feel free to scoff at that, but it went up more than expected. The expectation was for an increase of .2 of a percent.

And Empire Manufacturing was down over 3 percent. So, again, the Empire Manufacturing Index coming in below expectations. Was it not? We're watching manufacturing just to get a read on whether this is going to be significant weakness in the coming months, in the coming quarters, or whether this is something fleeting.

Again, many economists -- you've heard this from Ben Bernanke as well -- that they thought that the recent weakness we've seen in the U.S. economy was related to the weather here, the tsunami, and the earthquake and tsunami over in Japan, that there was a interruption in business and activity, an interruption in manufacturing activity in the wake of that horrible disaster, and because of the weather here at home. And then the spike in gas prices on top of that.

But again, we're watching consumer prices, and not a worrisome increase in core prices, but still up more than expected.

MCSHANE: A little bit, but there's not really much in terms of signs of inflation. And the headline figure, if anything, we're seeing consumer prices go down, and that's interesting because it's the first time it's happened in quite a while. A little over a year since the last time we saw a drop in consumer prices.

MCDOWELL: Energy.

MCSHANE: Yes, absolutely.

MCDOWELL: A decrease in energy prices.

Well, speaking of energy, a man who always gets Connell and me fired up, Lou Dobbs, of the Fox Business Network, is coming up.

Then later on, we're going to talk with Dr. Keith Ablow, about the release of Casey Anthony.

Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: This country's pristine credit rating now tarnished. For the second time in two days, the U.S. government's AAA rating is being threatened with a downgrade. Standard & Poor's now saying there's a 50 percent chance it will cut that AAA as the impasse over the debt ceiling continues.

However, maybe some progress is being made in the talks between the White House and congressional leaders. At 9:00 a.m. Eastern, the Republicans will come out and give a press conference. Two hours later, President Obama will talk to the media, 11:00 a.m. Eastern Time, which of course you can watch both here on Fox Business.

And the Pentagon suffering one of the largest cyberattacks ever -- 24,000 files, some extremely sensitive, stolen. And U.S. officials believe it was the work of a foreign government.

And Casey Anthony scheduled to be released from prison on Sunday after being acquitted of murdering her daughter, but there are major concerns about her safety once she is out of jail.

Good morning, everybody. I'm Dagen McDowell.

That is Connell McShane.

So we're going to have a busy day, and we've got some incredible guests coming up as well. Lou Dobbs will be here in just a few minutes, and then Dr. Keith Ablow on the release of Casey Anthony.

MCSHANE: Yes. And we'll talk to Lou about the debt ceiling. And, of course, the Republicans are going to talk about it themselves at the top of the hour with their news conference, then the president at 11:00.

Let's look at the markets. We had the consumer price numbers, and the first decline in consumer prices in over a year that we just reported a moment ago.

Dow futures are up a little bit this morning. Get a quick check on the -- Dagen mentioned the importance of energy in these inflation figures. The oil price this morning is $96 and change, so we're up by almost 40 cents from where we closed it out yesterday.

MCDOWELL: And Diane is about ready to give you more on those inflation numbers.

Hey, Diane.

MACEDO: Hi, guys.

Well, as you touched on, we just got the latest on retail inflation. And consumer prices in June came down .2 of a percent.

Now, that was a bigger-than-expected decline. The estimate was for a decline of .1 of a percent. If you factor out the volatile food and energy component, the so-called core number rose .3 of a percent. And the estimate there was for an increase of .2 of a percent.

We also got the latest reading on Empire Manufacturing. That index came in with a reading of negative 3.76. The estimate was for a positive reading of 4.50. That, last month, it came in at negative 7.8, a number that rocked the markets.

Standard & Poor's is threatening to downgrade the U.S.' AAA credit rating because of the debt ceiling impasse. But S&P is concerned about the big debt picture, so it could even still cut the rating if a deal to raise the debt limit is reached.

The ratings firm says there's a 50-50 chance it will cut the rating in the next three months. And this comes just a day after Moody's put the country's debt on watch for a possible downgrade as well.

Google's earnings, meanwhile, blew out the estimates. Shares are up about 70 bucks in the pre-market trading. The company is posting a profit of $2.5 billion. Adjusted earnings came in at $8.74 a share, and revenue jumped nearly $7 billion.

Now for a check on the day's top stories.

Connell, let's throw it back to you.

(NEWSBREAK)

MCSHANE: All right. IMUS IN THE MORNING continues here on Fox Business, leading up to "VARNEY & COMPANY" at 9:20 Eastern Time.

But our next guest here to talk a little bit more about these debt negotiations in Washington. Lou Dobbs, the host of "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT" on the Fox Business Networkis joining us now on the telephone.

Good morning, Lou. Good to talk to you again.

LOU DOBBS, HOST, "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT": Good morning, Connell. Great to be with you guys.

MCSHANE: Always good to talk to you, come to think of it.

You know, here is what I want to ask you about these debt negotiations. We talked about -- earlier this hour we were pointing out that this guy Jay Powell from the Bipartisan Policy Center is going to come in and brief the Republicans today. He worked for President Bush, and he believes August 2nd -- and he's a Republican, remember -- is a real deadline.

And there's been some debate over that. He says you're $130 billion short in terms of paying the bills in the month of August if we don't get a deal done. So he's going to try to convince, it seems to me, some of the rank and file and the Republicans that have doubts, that this is a real deadline.

What do you think?

DOBBS: Well, I think that's terrific. And I think that the Bipartisan Center has done some terrific work in their analysis of what is truncated month in August, and projecting those -- what will be $134 billion shortfall in total received versus disbursement.

But again, remember, the issue here is over specifically Social Security, with a $2.6 trillion trust fund made up of the tax payments of literally millions of Americans and millions of employers over the course of the time. So, the question would be, why would that -- why would the Treasury Department not sell treasury instruments to pay and to keep current with Social Security recipients?

I mean, it's absolutely, to me, unforgivable that the president has threatened older Americans who depend on Social Security. And this is the focus that should -- you know, I think really is appropriate. That is, why in the world are we permitting fear mongering from the nation's commander- in-chief?

MCDOWELL: It was very obviously, Lou, a scare tactic. But I've heard people in trying to explain -- I've heard people trying to explain away this deadline, this August 2nd deadline. Not explain it away, but people saying -- you cited the $134 billion number.

People came out and said, well, hey, we have X amount of revenue coming in the door. We have $172 billion coming in the door in flows. We can cover the interest on the debt. We can cover all the Social Security payments. We can Medicare and Medicaid.

But they're not addressing the other side of it, and that is we have a shortfall of $134 billion just in the month of August.

DOBBS: Correct. And by the way, that's not the entire month of August.

MCDOWELL: Right. It's a truncated month based on the business day starting on August the 2nd.

DOBBS: Right. And even at that, people still want to avoid two issues here.

One is, why have we waited until this particular moment in time, with a couple of weeks ago to that deadline? One is, it is the preference of this administration to create urgency and a crisis, if you will, so that they can just press through whatever they want.

Senator Mitch McConnell, accommodating him with his proposal, which I think is shameful again, because this is a serious matter. We're looking at $2.6 trillion in the trust fund that the Treasury Department can't find, nor have they been willing to, nor has any national news organization succeeded in finding out where that $2.6 trillion is. I mean --

MCDOWELL: Well, the fund loaned it to the federal government, but didn't get treasuries in return. They're like non-marketable securities.

(LAUGHTER)

DOBBS: Exactly. And to the degree to which that is -- you know, if you were a small business doing what the United States government is doing with those receipts, you'd be in big trouble for (INAUDIBLE) funds. And this is very serious business because it just tells you how -- the madness that is gripping this nation of fiscal policy.

MCSHANE: Let's talk a little bit -- I also want to revisit something you just said on the Mitch McConnell plan from the report.

DOBBS: Sure.

MCSHANE: Because Bret Baier was on with us earlier today from Washington, and he says that's gaining momentum, all his sources on Capitol Hill.

DOBBS: Right.

MCSHANE: And it seems like --

DOBBS: That's what we reported last night as well.

MCSHANE: -- that's the only game in town right now. But you say he's accommodating the administration.

DOBBS: No question about it.

MCSHANE: And it's shameful.

DOBBS: I think it's shameful that we are sitting here talking about, with all of these issues, a way in which to disentangle this confrontation so that no one is accountable to the American people for the results. You know, this is -- I talked with Karl Rove last night about it, Connell, and Karl has great regard, as do I, for Senator McConnell's political acumen and capacity, but the issue here is a nation teetering on the verge of becoming a debtor nation in perpetuity.

We are sucking the lifeblood out of our economic system. What sense does it make that we have our Federal Reserve system injecting $2.5 trillion into our financial system to stimulate it, while at the same time we are sucking $4 trillion out of the economy for the purpose of a government that is both ineffective, unproductive, and not contributing in any way whatsoever to innovation and to the bigger (ph) and vitality of this great, free enterprise capitalist economy?

MCDOWELL: Lou, really quickly though, do you think maybe the whole attitude around the country changes even more? I've had a lot of conversations with people mentioning these deficit figures just for the month of August, and when they say, well, how much are we short here? I'm like, $134 billion.

And the reaction has been, $134 billion in a month? And maybe they're waking up to the fact that we're in a deep hole that it's going to be hard to get out of.

DOBBS: Dagen, I think you're talking about the unintended consequence that is extraordinarily positive for all of us. I think by putting these things into terms that people understand -- that is, their Social Security check in particular, paychecks for our troops -- this is coming home now to a lot of -- to millions of Americans who have not paid attention to what has been a scam in Washington, D.C., for decades. Namely, public financing of programs that are unsustainable.

And unfortunately, many of those entitlement programs now, upon which literally tens of millions of Americans depend. And that we need real leadership at this moment, and what we're getting are political maneuvers.

MCSHANE: And maybe this wakes people up to that.

Lou, thank you.

DOBBS: Thank you.

MCSHANE: And we always appreciate it.

We'll watch Lou tonight on the Fox Business Network, 7:00 p.m. Eastern, is "LOU DOBBS TONIGHT.".

MCDOWELL: And Dr. Keith Ablow is up next. We'll talk about the release of Casey Anthony this weekend.

And next week, Mr. Imus is back live from the ranch with Tom Friedman, Sean Hannity, "Blonde on Blonde." And the battle of the bands will continue with our stage manager's band, the Clatty Lads.

MCSHANE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: They'll be a blast.

MCDOWELL: I have a few news items I would like to bring to your attention this morning, Mr. McShane.

MCSHANE: Well, the floor is always yours.

MCDOWELL: Not that you don't do a lot of reading and work on your own, but Mila Kunis, the very, very beautiful actress --

MCSHANE: Yes?

MCDOWELL: -- will be attending the Marine Corps ball --

MCSHANE: Oh, that's great.

MCDOWELL: -- in the fall with Sergeant Scott Moore, who got a date by making that YouTube video.

MCSHANE: Bernard brought that story up yesterday on IMUS IN THE MORNING.

MCDOWELL: There was a report out -- a couple of media outlets reported that she was not going to go because she was busy. She was shooting two movies simultaneously. But she is going. Her representative saying it's a date.

MCSHANE: Nice.

MCDOWELL: So that's just one of the items that makes me feel good.

MCSHANE: I feel terrific after that.

MCDOWELL: Warm inside.

It's a case, by the way, that has captivated the world. And now Casey Anthony is getting out of prison this weekend.

Fox News contributor and author Dr. Keith Ablow is working on a book about the case, and we're lucky to have him join us on the phone this morning.

Dr. Keith, good to talk to you.

DR. KEITH ABLOW, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Hey. Good to talk to you.

MCDOWELL: Dr. Keith, we keep talking about her safety and how she might disguise herself, where she might live. But, really, she needs to work on herself as a person, does she not? Is it an insurmountable task that she faces in terms of trying to become a normal person?

ABLOW: Well, these things are extraordinarily difficult. When you are as disordered as Casey Anthony is, in the particular ways that she suffers with, it's going to take an extraordinarily gifted therapist and a new willingness on her part to explore the darkest parts of her life experience and the way she thinks in order for her to have that chance.

Is there that chance? Yes, there really is. There always is, but it's like cancer. Right?

Is there a chance for a cure in every case? Yes, there is. Are there some cases that are beyond help? Yes, there are.

MCSHANE: Right. Now, Dagen mentioned a moment ago, Dr. Keith, that you're working on a book about this whole situation.

What will you look into specifically in the book? What's it going to be about?

ABLOW: Well, it's inside the mind of Casey Anthony. And so, this book is going to use a lens -- you know, the lens of forensic psychiatry that is part and parcel of the work I've done in the past 20 years -- to really illuminate, why is Caylee Anthony no longer on the planet? What happened? What's the psychological reason that this story unfolded, so that people can actually understand.

It's one thing to have headlines. It's another to say, oh, well, that now makes sense to me, that it occurred in this way or might well have occurred in this way.

MCDOWELL: Dr. Keith, how much work has she had done, psychiatric work on her, since she is 's been in prison for the last three years or so?

ABLOW: Well, she's no doubt had multiple psychiatric evaluations. We know that she was evaluated as to her competency to stand trial, but that probably wasn't the first time, the most recent.

She clearly established a relationship with a minister in prison that seemingly became tremendously important to her. And, you know, the isolation of being jailed, simply that, removing herself from all intoxicants -- well, those that can't seep through the bars of your cell or, you know, the elevated kind of communication that you might have with somebody else imprisoned there -- that's another kind of drug -- but literally that isolation works its own kind of magic, if you will, on a person's mind.

She deprived of multiple intoxicants: sex, alcohol, shopping. And so those things can clarify a person's thinking, too, that quiet isolation.

MCSHANE: Does it make it more likely then if you're in that situation that you engage in those activities, or whatever you want to call them, when you get out, because you haven't had them in so long?

ABLOW: Well, listen, I have a blog that's going up in about 30 minutes on FoxNews.com in the opinion section, six things that Casey Anthony is likely to do, five things she should do.

Among the six, number one, find a sexual partner. That's the most likely thing she will do. It's not the most important thing for her to do, but that is the drug that has been so important to her in her life to date, and she's going to go searching for that drug right away.

MCDOWELL: Dr. Keith, can she have any kind of life to speak of the rest of her life?

ABLOW: You know, I've been amazed in my practice -- and, you know, some of the people I work with aren't incarcerated. First of all, some of them are just regular folks who are suffering with depression and the rest of things.

But of the people I've worked with who were involved with violent acts, not all of them come to me because they're incarcerated. Some committed violent acts in the past and are looking to resurrect themselves.

So, can she? The notoriety is not in her favor. The availability of intoxicants is not in her favor, including fame.

MCSHANE: Right.

ABLOW: But it's possible, remotely possible, and only through insight- oriented psychotherapy.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:52JD-J8W1-JD2T-F24V-00000-00U.S. Jobs Number Shows Growth; Rival Bid for Big Board; Damage to Japan's Economy2011-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:42:00ZLexisNexisU.S. Jobs Number Shows Growth; Rival Bid for Big Board; Damage to Japan's Economy

RICHARD QUEST, HOST, QUEST MEANS BUSINESS: It is a job lot, U.S. payrolls grow for the sixth straight month.

Muscling in, Nasdaq/OMX mount a rival bid for the Big Board.

And the guess work is over. Sorry clear evidence of real damage now at Japan's economy.

It is a Friday. We're together. I'm Richard Quest and I mean business.

Good evening.

April the 1st, and the start of a new quarter, and of course, April Fool's Day. The international festival of pranks. I can hear you already asking, will they, or won't they? Well, we may. Or we may not. And the only way you will find out is if you keep watching.

And you'll want to keep watching because we lead off tonight with America, the land of opportunity, potentially again; hundreds of thousands are heading back to work. The U.S. economy gained more than 200,000 jobs last month and it sealed a solid 6 months of growth rates in the States.

Look at the way they have rose. It was a bit of a blip in January after some winter weather. But that growth, the trend seems to be heading firmly up. The unemployment rate in the U.S. now stands at 8.8 percent. Still high by the standards of developed countries and certainly by the United States, but that is the best number that has been seen in two years. And most of the growth now starting to come from the private sector, which added 230,000 jobs. The public sector battling against these cuts, of course, with the cuts, cut 14,000 and recovery is most definitely not on the cards. Certainly as budget deficits, both local, state, and federal level, continue; 13.5 million people are still out of work in the United States.

Jeff Joerres is the CEO and chairman of Manpower Group, the new name for Manpower Inc., one of the world's largest employment agencies. Jeff is with me from Milwaukee.

Jeff, you just heard me summarize the situation. Good jobs, good private sector job growth, a fall in the unemployment, but it is still not enough.

Believe it or not, changing your clothes when you get back inside the house, that could help the concern, as well, as a lot of the pollen clings on right to your clothing and makes you sneeze all around the house after you've come indoors. So, you're wondering why you're feeling the symptoms when you're inside? That could be the reason. You can change your clothes.

But here is a storm system that is entering the picture. That, again, will help mix up the atmosphere a little bit as we head on into Saturday, partly to mostly cloudy skies around London, and Western Europe could get some showers out of this. And also across the north, a few showers.

So, the temperatures are going to cool down, that'll suppress some of the pollen levels, there, in the next few days, and the conditions are going to improve. But really, the warmest air mass still stays to the south, here, across portions of southern France into Spain, Portugal getting well above-average readings, some 10 to 12 degrees above average over the next couple of days.

And if you've got some travel plans out there, looks like travel not going to be affected by this much, as we're seeing breezy conditions and, again, a few showers possible. But all in all, an improving forecast for Mr. Quest out there, and perhaps some of the folks that are dealing with the allergies, Richard.

QUEST: We thank you for that. I'm not sure whether knowing about the allergies actually makes it any better, but Pedram, we do thank you. I think the most extraordinary thing is the way I'm finding them coming on as I get older. There must be a moral in there somewhere. Pedram, have a good weekend.

JAVAHERI: Yes.

QUEST: Now, finally to you, don't say you weren't warned. April Fool's Day on a week when we've spoken to a number of the top airlines. The entire industry, why oh why is it the airline industry that decided to get April Fools silly?

For example, Virgin Atlantic, they announced that they were growing fresh herbs and vegetables for upper class passengers in the galley. Apparently, the galley would be onboard, and they promised fresh mint for mojitos.

That was an April Fool.

Ryanair had everyone confused. They said they had child-free flights from October. The press release was dated April the 1st, but it was released, seemingly, yesterday, because I read that story. So, Ryanair -- I'm not sure who the final fool was, Michael. Your press release came out early. Anyway, we still had that one.

And then, finally, yes. We did it to you. Urchin Airways, kids only flights, the opposite of Ryanair, kids only, sorry. April Fool!

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED GIRL: You've been April Fooled.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: They were, of course, in on the joke. And that is QUEST MEANS BUSINESS for tonight. I'm Richard Quest in London. Whatever you're up to in the weekend ahead, have a good weekend. Thank you for your time and attention. MARKETPLACE AFRICA is next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ROBYN CURNOW, CNN HOST: You're watching MARKETPLACE AFRICA. I'm Robyn Curnow here on the streets of Johannesburg. We begin this week's show with a look at a multibillion-dollar industry that is both dangerous and illegal -- counterfeit drugs.

The World Health Organization estimates that a third of all medicines in the developing world are fake. So, how do you choose between what is real and what isn't? Lives are lost in that gamble. But as Christian Purefoy now reports, mobile technology is helping Africans to make an educated choice.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CHRISTIAN PUREFOY, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Armed police cracking down hard on Nigeria's fake drug sellers. But, say the authorities, these raids are not enough to stop counterfeit drugs flooding Nigeria's streets.

GARBA MACDONALD, DEPARTMENT DIRECTOR OF ENFORCEMENT, NAFDAC: Considering the level of poverty, people will want to go for the cheapest.

PUREFOY (on camera): And the big men behind the sale of these drugs? Do they pose a danger to you and your men?

MACDONALD: Yes, they do. They are problems because they can organize, they have the money, they can organize thugs to attack us. We cannot deal with this without more policemen.

PUREFOY: So, this is big money.

MACDONALD: Oh, it's big money, yes, sure. Big money.

PUREFOY (voice-over): As Femi Sorenmekun, director of a local diabetes drug company, explains, the major problem is identifying which box of drugs is real, and which is fake. Until now, with the introduction of a small scratch card packaged with all his medications.

FEMI SOREMEKUN, MANAGING DIRECTOR, BIOCHEM PHARMACEUTICALS: Then they scratch it, and upon scratching it, a number is revealed.

PUREFOY (on camera): If we text that now -- ?

SOREMEKUN: Definitely, if you text that now, you're going to --

PUREFOY: What happens?

SOREMEKUN: You're going to get a message telling you --

PUREFOY: Can we try it?

SOREMEKUN: Yes, you can.

PUREFOY: There you go. So, that's almost immediate.

SOREMEKUN: Yes. Almost immediate.

PUREFOY: But when someone receives this text, it says "OK," they know that drug is original.

SOREMEKUN: Is original.

PUREFOY: Has it worked? Has it helped your business? Has it helped the sales?

SOREMEKUN: Yes, it has. We've been able to capture most of our market share back. Because we can't eliminate fake 100 percent. But what we've lost, we've captured it back, and we can see some growth, now, in the business.

PUREFOY (voice-over): The idea is borrowed from the scratch cards sold on street corners across Africa use to top up mobile phones with credit.

Applying this scratch card innovation to the drug market is the idea of Ashifi Gogo.

ASHIFI GOGO, CEO, SPROXIL, INC.: The good thing is the consumer is not paying. The government is not paying, as well. And it's the pharm companies that are paying Sproxil for the service. The rationale being they can recoup market share that's been lost to counterfeiters.

So, in some sense, the counterfeiters are paying for the service, which puts a smile on lots of people's faces, I guess, except for the counterfeiters.

PUREFOY (voice-over): A simple tool that investigators hope will make raids like this one less necessary. Christian Purefoy, CNN, Lagos, Nigeria.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CURNOW: So, anti-malarial drugs are the most commonly counterfeited medication here in Africa. The United Nations estimates that in some parts of the continent, between 50 to 60 percent of all anti-insective drugs don't have acceptable levels of their active ingredients.

And more disturbingly, a World Health Organization Study found that Ghana was the worst affected, 67 percent of their most common anti-malarial drugs were found to have failed potency tests.

Now, up next, he coined the phrase "BRIC" to describe the top emerging-market economies. But what does he have to say about South Africa's entry into that elite club? Up next on MARKETPLACE AFRICA, we interview leading economist Jim O'Neill.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CURNOW: Welcome back to MARKETPLACE AFRICA. They're known as the fastest-growing emerging markets, Brazil, Russia, India, and China. Together, they're known as BRIC, an acronym coined by our next guest on Face Time, Jim O'Neill, chairman of Goldman Sachs.

In the next few weeks, South Africa joins the BRIC summit in Beijing, hoping its inclusion will raise its status and prestige on the world stage. But Jim O'Neill now weighs in on whether he thinks South Africa really deserves a seat at that table.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JIM O'NEILL, CHAIRMAN, GOLDMAN SACHS ASSET MANAGEMENT: To be a BRIC, it has to be an economy that is really at the core, today, or likely to be in the future, of the world economy. So, it has to be big enough to be economically impactful on everybody else.

And so, against that general background, an economy that is already three to five percent of global GDP or is likely to be on in a vaguely foreseeable future. And if you go with that definition, there's only a clear four there are, Brazil, Russia, India, India, and China.

To be a "Next 11" country, it is literally a phrase that I dreamed up seven years ago as a result of people saying, well, why just those four? Why not Indonesia? Why not Mexico? Why not Turkey? Why not South Africa? Et cetera et cetera. And it's a phrase to describe the next 11 largest population countries from the emerging world.

NIMA ELBAGIR, CNN CORRESPONDENT: If the N-11 is such a fluid --

O'NEILL: Yes.

ELBAGIR: -- concept, why do you think there has been so much controversy over South Africa jumping over the N-11 to be part of the BRICS club.

O'NEILL: South Africa's so unique and, in this context, quite odd. Because South Africa has some aspects of development, particularly financial markets, some aspects of the better standards of Western practices in terms of regulatory matters and Western law. And with that, there has been historic trade organizations that South Africa's linked to, particularly with Brazil and India.

And so, with the whole growth of the BRIC idea, particularly when it became a BRIC political club, for South Africa to be not part of it is obviously something that South African leaders feel a little bit, "What's going on here?"

Beyond that, I'm not sure why South Africa's managed to leap above it. Because if you look at the criteria I said earlier about what's a BRIC and what's a Next 11, South Africa doesn't even come close to -- certainly, not a BRIC. South African economy at, what? $350 billion is half the sum of global GDP.

So, it's nowhere near constituting a BRIC, and without staggering productivity improvements and major immigration or improvements in birthrates, et cetera, et cetera, it's never going to get there.

South Africa's really stimulated my mind to explore this further, because there are some others, like Poland, Saudi Arabia, who have more reason to be irked about these things, perhaps, than just South Africa. Because, of course, when you look at the Next 11 definition, South Africa doesn't actually have that many people, either. And in the context of the continent, Nigeria is the place that really matters.

ELBAGIR: I was going to say, do you think they've missed the trick by taking in South Africa rather than Nigeria?

O'NEILL: I think it's been, because the South African leaders and leading intellects have been so persistent about it and maybe the Chinese and Indians and others thought, "You know what? OK, guys. If it shuts you up, come in."

But there is another angle to it, of course, that I'm sure South Africa has perhaps played on the notion that because they do have developed markets and western government standards in some areas, they've said, "Look, we're the gateway to the rest of Africa," and that's certainly an argument with some legitimacy.

ELBAGIR: What would you advice -- if you were advising the South African government, what should they do to earn their place at the BRIC table?

O'NEILL: That South African --

ELBAGIR: The South African government. Or do you think it's a -- anyhow, it's a lost cause?

O'NEILL: No, I don't. No, nowhere is a lost cause. I think South African leaders have to be bolder about the basics and not be so worried about what club they're in or not. They've got acceptance, they're in the G-20, they've been invited to the big political meeters -- leaders' meeting, and they're there.

What they've now got to do is, as with the World Cup, turn an event into some lasting improvement. Stop thinking that because of Apartheid and other tragic historical things, stop thinking that world owes South Africa something for its past, and do things to create a better environment where you can attract a lot more international business.

And most importantly, embrace all your own people in a competitive, open way and find everybody jobs.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CURNOW: Is South Africa qualified to be a member of BRIC? Tell us what you think. We're having a discussion on our Facebook page. But for now, let's just take a look at what's trending this week.

Foreign mining firms in Zimbabwe are scrambling following President Robert Mugabe's demand that they must sell a majority stake to local black Zimbabweans within six months. Shares at major mining companies dropped sharply upon the news.

The regulation follows an indigenization act signed into law three years ago, which aims to make foreign companies junior partners in Zimbabwe.

And Kumba Iron Ore is proposing a $7 billion steel plant in South Africa to help reduce unemployment.

President Jacob Zuma has asked businesses to help create 5 million jobs in the coming decade. The proposed plant would create 3,000 jobs and export up to five billion tons of steel each year to buyers in Asia.

So, if you have any ideas on who we should interview or what stories we should be doing, please do connect with us. We're on Facebook, we're on Twitter, and you can e-mail us. We'd love to hear what you have to say.

But until next week, for me, Robyn Curnow, here in Johannesburg, good- bye.

END
